title: Guide to Online Ethics Applications (Wrexham Research Information System (WRIS) / Vidatum Academic)
text:
1-2-Project Dates
Make sure to set your Project Start Date before you submit your ethics application. Many students overlook the two‑week review period, and applications are often returned for small corrections such as incorrect dates. To avoid delays, ensure your start date allows enough time for the review process.
For the Project End Date, give yourself the maximum amount of time possible. Think about your dissertation deadline and set your end date to at least 2–4 weeks before your final submission to ensure you have enough time for data collection, analysis, and writing.

title: Guide to Online Ethics Applications (Wrexham Research Information System (WRIS) / Vidatum Academic)
text:
1-5-External Approval
Another straightforward section — this should simply be a “no.” However, students would only need External Approval if their research involves an organisation, setting, or participant group outside the University, where that organisation has its own ethics or permission procedures. Examples include:

Schools or Colleges — Many schools require their own safeguarding and research approval before any contact with pupils or staff.



NHS settings — Any research involving patients, staff, data, or premises within the NHS requires approval through the Health Research Authority (HRA).



Charities, workplaces, or community organisations — If you intend to recruit participants or collect data through an external organisation, they may have internal research governance processes you must follow.



Private companies or clinical services — Some services (e.g., counselling agencies, private clinics) require written permission or internal ethical review.

In short, a student needs External Approval whenever another organisation acts as a gatekeeper to participants, data, or locations, and that organisation insists on its own permission procedure.

title: Guide to Online Ethics Applications (Wrexham Research Information System (WRIS) / Vidatum Academic)
text:
2-1-Research Aims
Provide your research aims and objectives of your dissertation project.

In this section, clearly state what your dissertation project intends to achieve.
Your aim should give an overall statement of the purpose of your study, while your objectives should break this down into specific, achievable steps. These must align with your research question and the methods you intend to use.

Please provide details of your research design(Please use lay language free from technical terms) 

Next, briefly outline how you plan to conduct your research. This may include your methodology (e.g., experimental, survey, qualitative interviews), sampling approach, data‑collection techniques, and any key procedures. Keep this section concise but clear enough for reviewers to understand your planned process.

Describe the potential benefits and impacts of your research, this can involve improving our current knowledge of the literature, how to improve a service etc.

Here, explain how your research may be valuable. Potential benefits might include:

Contributing to or updating existing psychological literature
Highlighting gaps in current knowledge
Informing practice or improving a service
Providing insights that could guide future research or interventions


You do not need to guarantee outcomes—simply outline the possible positive contributions your work may offer.

2-2-Gatekeeper
If you are requesting permission to access an individual or a group of potential research participants through an external organisation, you must select “Yes” for this question. This applies whenever an organisation, gatekeeper, or authorised person is required to grant you access.
Please also speak with your supervisor, as some organisations are classed as higher‑risk for ethical review. These may require additional scrutiny, longer approval times, or further documentation before your application can be approved.

title: Guide to Online Ethics Applications (Wrexham Research Information System (WRIS) / Vidatum Academic)
text:
2-3-Risk
Please refer back to the BPS Ethical Principles to guide how you will minimise risks within your study. You can access the full BPS Code of ethics and conduct on the BPS website.
Nonetheless, the primary ethical principles include:

Respect – valuing the dignity, rights, and autonomy of all participants.
Competence – working within your abilities and seeking supervision where necessary.
Responsibility – ensuring participant welfare, avoiding harm, and managing risk appropriately.
Integrity – conducting research honestly, transparently, and without deception unless ethically justified.

title: Guide to Online Ethics Applications (Wrexham Research Information System (WRIS) / Vidatum Academic)
text:
2-4-Method

Interviews - 1-to-1 interviews between the participant (interviewee) and yourself (the interviewer)
Focus Groups - thematic discussions between participants.
Survey / Questionnaire - Psychometric questionnaires
Observation - Observation to obtain inter-rater scoring.
Non-Invasive experiment - Most psychological / cognitive experiments would be considered as this.
Invasive experiment - This can suggest several things. The one that can be attributed mostly for this high-stress psychological experiments or invasive electrode placements.
Secondary Analysis - You should only do secondary analysis if you are doing a quantitative analysis of the data, such as meta-analysis or a meta synthesis. Therefore this excludes systematic reviews or analyses of previous qualitative research.
Human Tissue – Collecting, storing, or analysing biological samples (e.g., blood, saliva, DNA) to investigate physiological, genetic, or health-related research questions.
Audits / Service Evaluations taking place in the NHS – Assessing existing healthcare services or practices to determine effectiveness, quality, or compliance with standards, rather than generating new generalisable research knowledge.
Internet-mediated research / data mining – Collecting or analysing data gathered through online platforms, social media, forums, digital archives, or large datasets to explore behaviours, attitudes, or trends.
Animals – Conducting research involving live animals to study behaviour, biology, or physiological processes under controlled or observational conditions.
Environmental Methods – Investigating how physical or social environments influence behaviour, wellbeing, or health (e.g., noise, space design, natural vs urban settings).
Visual / Audio Methods – Using images, video, sound recordings, or multimedia materials as primary data sources to analyse behaviour, communication, or experiences.
Auto-ethnography – A reflective research approach where researchers use their own personal experiences as data to explore cultural, social, or psychological phenomena.
Other – Research methods that do not fit into the listed categories and require further explanation or justification within the research proposal.

text:
3-1-Data Type
You have two sections to fill out here; what the data is and how will the data be collected. Just be as pedantic as possible and try to give as much information out as possible so that the reviewer understand what you are trying to do. Sometimes being vague can be at your disadvantage as then the reviewer will question if there’s any ethical considerations you had left out in your application as data is important. S
Specifically to consider, you must highlight why you are collecting specific demographic data. As the are protected characteristics that must be protected unless past research demands it. Essentially, protected characteristics are personal identity attributes that require extra care in research because misuse or disclosure could cause harm, discrimination, or distress. Therefore, if you are trying to obtain specific demographics then please make sure to reference why it is necessary for your research to obtain these characteristics in alignment to your aims and objectives.
A list of common protected characteristics relevant to psychological research:

Age – Including children, adolescents, and older adults, who may require additional consent or capacity considerations.
Disability – Physical, sensory, cognitive, or mental impairments; includes neurodiversity and mental health conditions.
Gender reassignment – Transgender and gender-diverse identities, including transition history.
Marriage and civil partnership – Relevant when research concerns legal, social, or relational status.
Pregnancy and maternity – Including pregnancy status, postnatal experiences, or fertility-related issues.
Race / ethnicity – Including nationality, skin colour, ethnic or cultural background.
Religion or belief – Religious affiliation, spiritual beliefs, or lack of belief.
Sex – Typically referring to biological sex.
Sexual orientation – Sexual identity, attraction, or behaviour.

Ethics committees should and will often ask:

Is this characteristic essential to the research aims?
Could participants be identified or harmed if data were disclosed?
Are recruitment, consent, and reporting respectful and inclusive?

You must clearly describe how your data will be collected or generated. In most cases, data should be collected using approved platforms such as JISC (for surveys), Gorilla.sc (for experimental tasks), Panopto (for interviews / focus groups). If you are collecting data in person without using a dedicated platform, you must outline a clear and structured procedure to ensure that data are collected consistently, handled securely, and stored appropriately on University One Drive.
If your study involves any paper-based materials, you must specify how these will be managed and securely disposed of, including prompt placement into confidential waste bins once data have been transferred or are no longer required. Careful consideration of these procedures is essential, as face-to-face data collection is subject to closer ethical scrutiny, particularly in relation to how participant data are handled, stored, and protected.

Wrexham University recommends that all research data should be stored on the University server or your university Office 365 accounts as a secure protected and backed up service. Any physical data should be stored securely on University site. Further guidance on the safe storage of research data can be found on the UK Data Service Webpages.

3-3-Access
In this section, you must specify who will have access to the data for the duration of the research project. Access should normally be restricted to you as the student researcher and your supervisor. If your project is advanced in nature or may require technical or methodological support, you should also include psychology technicians as authorised data handlers within the application. Limiting access to only those directly involved in the research helps ensure confidentiality, data security, and compliance with ethical and data protection requirements.

Student research data should be stored until the end of studies or transferred to the supervisor if required to be retained for a longer period. If required for longer, then necessary data to support or validate a research project’s observations, findings or outputs should be retained in an appropriate format and storage facility for at least 10 years

title: Guide to Online Ethics Applications (Wrexham Research Information System (WRIS) / Vidatum Academic)
text:
3-6-Dissemination
In this section, you should explain where and how your findings will be shared. For most undergraduate and postgraduate projects, this will include:
Submission as part of a dissertation, thesis, or assessed coursework
Presentation to academic staff or examiners
Possible inclusion in poster presentations, internal conferences, or teaching materials
If there is any intention to share findings more widely (e.g. conferences, journal articles, public reports), this should be stated clearly. You should also indicate that results will be reported in an aggregated and anonymised form, rather than at an individual participant level.
Students are not expected to publish their work, but they should be clear and realistic about potential academic dissemination routes. If you seek to publish your work then please speak to your supervisor.
Something to note however, you should demonstrate awareness of how dissemination could affect participants or groups represented in the data. Key ethical considerations typically include:

Anonymity and confidentiality – ensuring that no individual participant can be identified in written reports, presentations, or figures.
Sensitive or protected characteristics – taking care not to stigmatise, stereotype, or misrepresent individuals or groups, particularly where protected characteristics are involved.
Responsible reporting – avoiding sensationalised language, overgeneralisation, or causal claims that are not supported by the data.
Data minimisation – reporting only what is necessary to address the research questions.
Participant dignity – ensuring findings are presented respectfully, even when results are unexpected or negative.

If findings could be misinterpreted or cause distress, students should note how they will contextualise and explain results carefully. In the end, you need to show your understanding who will see your results, how they will be shared, and how you will protect participants from harm or identification when doing so.

3-7-Storage
Your data should be fully anonymised form as this is best practice to protect your participants. Specifically, this is when the information does not relate to an identified or identifiable person or to personal data rendered anonymous in such a manner that the data subject is not or no longer identifiable.
Please avoid going for identifiable information as this will tagged as high risk and the wait time for your application will extend from 2 weeks.

title: Guide to Online Ethics Applications (Wrexham Research Information System (WRIS) / Vidatum Academic)
text:
3-8-Data Processing
The anonymisation process should be applied as early as possible and maintained throughout the research lifecycle. Nevertheless, this will vary if you are using specific platforms or methodological approaches. Therefore, I have highlighted the following steps as good practice:
Removal of direct identifiers - All direct identifiers (e.g. names, email addresses, student numbers, IP addresses, or usernames) must be removed from the dataset immediately after data collection.
Use of participant codes - Each participant should be assigned a unique, non-identifiable code (e.g. P001, P002). Any document linking participant identities to codes (a “key”) must be stored separately from the research data, in a secure location, and accessed only if absolutely necessary.
Handling of indirect identifiers - Indirect identifiers (e.g. age, gender, ethnicity, job role, or other demographic variables) should be collected only where relevant and reported in aggregated form. Categories may be collapsed where small cell sizes could risk identification.
Anonymisation of qualitative data - For interviews, open-text responses, or observational notes, identifying details (e.g. names of people, places, organisations, or unique events) must be removed or replaced with neutral descriptors (e.g. “[workplace]”, “[friend]”).
Secure storage of anonymised data - Anonymised datasets should be stored on approved, secure systems (e.g.University OneDrive) with restricted access. Identifiable raw data should not be shared or transferred unnecessarily.
Reporting and dissemination - Findings must be reported in a way that prevents identification of individuals or small groups, including careful use of quotations, figures, and tables.
Data retention and destruction - Any temporary files containing identifiable information should be securely deleted once anonymisation is complete and no longer required.

title: Ethics
text:
Document status and authorship This page has been generated collaboratively using artificial intelligence and human academic oversight. It is not a final or static policy document. Instead, it is a living, evolving resource intended to support psychology students across academic years in understanding and applying research ethics in practice. It should be read alongside formal university ethics procedures and supervisor guidance. Students are encouraged to consult only the sections relevant to their specific project rather than reading the document in its entirety; however, those intending to pursue psychology in an academic or research-focused context are strongly advised to engage with the full document, as it outlines foundational ethical principles and practices that are essential for academic psychological research.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Use this document as a practical guide alongside formal procedures
✅ Read only the sections that are directly relevant to your specific project
❌ Treat this as a final or exhaustive policy
❌ Feel obliged to read every section if it is not relevant to your study




This document is designed to support psychology students in preparing ethically sound research proposals and ethics applications. Its primary aim is to translate core ethical principles—particularly those articulated by the British Psychological Society (BPS)—into practical guidance that aligns with the expectations of Research Ethics Committees (RECs). The emphasis throughout is on ethical viability, feasibility, and institutional responsibility, rather than simply regulatory compliance.
It provides guidance on: practical implementation of ethics, common pitfalls for students, additional considerations for REC review, and guidance for managing sensitive or complex aspects of research.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Consult supervisors early and regularly
✅ Consider practical feasibility as well as ethical principles
❌ Assume mere adherence to rules ensures ethical approval
❌ Start data collection without REC approval





This guidance is grounded in the British Psychological Society (BPS) Code of Human Research Ethics: https://www.bps.org.uk/guideline/bps-code-human-research-ethics
The BPS framework emphasises practical values that must be operationalised in all psychology research. Additional ethical considerations incorporated here include confidentiality, researcher-participant boundaries, demographic justification, incentives, and environmental/social responsibility.


Researchers must recognise participants as autonomous agents with the right to make informed, voluntary decisions about participation.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Provide clear, accessible information and consent procedures
✅ Respect participant autonomy and withdrawal rights
❌ Coerce or mislead participants
❌ Deny or obscure withdrawal options




Research must be methodologically sound, theoretically justified, and conducted with honesty and transparency.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Use validated, appropriate methods
✅ Justify all methodological choices
❌ Conduct research without planning or justification
❌ Fabricate or misrepresent data or methods




Researchers must consider broader social, institutional, and cultural consequences of their work, including cultural sensitivity, inclusivity, and environmental/institutional risks.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Protect vulnerable groups and consider societal impacts
✅ Address potential misuses of findings
✅ Ensure cultural and demographic considerations are justified
✅ Mitigate environmental or institutional risks
❌ Conduct research likely to harm or stigmatise participants
❌ Ignore wider implications of findings




All research involves some level of risk. Ethical research requires these risks to be proportionate, justified, and actively mitigated.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Assess and mitigate risks
✅ Provide debriefing and support mechanisms
❌ Expose participants to unnecessary harm
❌ Assume participants can manage distress without support




Researchers must ensure participant data is kept confidential and anonymised wherever possible.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Anonymise or pseudonymise participant data
✅ Explain limits of confidentiality in consent forms
❌ Share identifiable data without explicit consent
❌ Store sensitive data on personal devices without institutional approval




Researchers must maintain professional boundaries and minimise power imbalances.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Maintain professional relationships and boundaries
✅ Avoid implicit pressure due to authority or institutional roles
❌ Exploit relationships or position of power
❌ Coerce participation through hierarchical pressure




Demographic questions must be justified and referenced. Only collect what is necessary for research objectives.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Collect only necessary demographic information
✅ Provide references for why each demographic variable is needed
❌ Collect all demographics without justification
❌ Include sensitive demographics without rationale




Use of incentives must not coerce participation. Participants can withdraw without losing rewards.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Explain incentives and withdrawal rights
✅ Ensure rewards are proportionate and ethical
❌ Use incentives to pressure participation
❌ Link participation to rewards in a way that creates undue influence






Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Provide clear rationale, methodology, and risk management plans
✅ Demonstrate researcher competence and supervision arrangements
❌ Submit vague or incomplete proposals
❌ Assume feasibility without evidence

Key areas of REC evaluation include:

Feasibility within the academic timeframe
Appropriateness of the sample and recruitment method
Data protection, storage, and GDPR compliance
Researcher competence and supervision
Institutional risk and liability







Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Use scales free for research or educational purposes
✅ Frame measures as assessing traits, experiences, or self-reported states
❌ Use copyrighted or proprietary measures without permission
❌ Attempt to diagnose or imply clinical assessment




Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Use university-approved, GDPR-compliant platforms
✅ Store data within institutional systems
❌ Use unapproved third-party platforms (e.g., Google Forms)
❌ Store participant data on personal or external cloud services




Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Conduct research in approved university facilities
✅ Book rooms, equipment, and risk assessments in advance
✅ Consult the Psychology Technician in regards to Experiments at psychology-technician@wrexham.ac.uk 
❌ Conduct research in unapproved or unsafe locations
❌ Ignore risk assessment procedures




Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Avoid deception unless necessary
✅ Fully debrief participants if deception is used
❌ Mislead participants unnecessarily
❌ Leave participants unaware of study purpose





You can find the appropriate ethics templates here: https://wrexham.ac.uk/research/our-research/research-ethics/how-to-apply–university-templates/





You can find the appropriate Wrexham Research Ethics Application site here:  https://wris.wrexham.ac.uk/main/research





You can find all the necessary information such as assessment briefs, rubrics, and tips on how to write your dissertation on the Moodle Page of PSY619 (Undergraduates), PSY771 (MSc Applied), PSY775 (MSc Conversion). 




 







Research involving sensitive topics requires careful ethical justification, proportionate risk management, and clear evidence that the research question cannot be addressed using less intrusive means. Sensitive topics may include, but are not limited to: trauma, abuse, violence, self-harm, suicide, substance use, discrimination, illegal behaviour, bereavement, sexual behaviour, or highly personal life experiences.
Research Ethics Committees assess sensitive-topic proposals with particular attention to participant vulnerability, likelihood of distress, and researcher preparedness. Students must demonstrate that they have anticipated potential emotional, psychological, or social risks and have put in place appropriate safeguards. This includes recognising that participants may have lived experience related to the topic, even if the study does not explicitly recruit clinical or vulnerable populations.
Ethical viability depends not only on what is being studied, but how it is studied. Question wording, task framing, sequencing of measures, and the context in which participation occurs all influence participant wellbeing. Studies that are overly intrusive, poorly justified, or disproportionate to the level of academic training are likely to be rejected or require substantial revision.
Students are expected to work closely with their supervisor when proposing sensitive topics and to engage in early ethical reflection rather than treating ethics as an administrative step. In many cases, Research Ethics Committees will expect explicit justification for why a sensitive topic is necessary, how harm will be minimised, and how participants will be supported both during and after participation.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Provide a clear theoretical and empirical justification for studying the sensitive topic
✅ Demonstrate proportionality between research aims and participant burden
✅ Include content warnings and remind participants of their right to skip questions
✅ Implement robust debriefing and signposting procedures
✅ Consult supervisors early and revise designs where risk is disproportionate
❌ Include sensitive questions without strong justification
❌ Use graphic, explicit, or unnecessarily detailed materials
❌ Assume participants will not experience distress
❌ Proceed without clear plans for managing adverse reactions

Sensitive-topic research can be ethically appropriate and academically valuable when designed with care, reflexivity, and proportional safeguards. Students must show the REC that participant welfare, feasibility, and institutional responsibility have been prioritised at every stage of the research process.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Justify and manage sensitive topics carefully
✅ Consult supervisors
❌ Use sensitive topics without safeguards
❌ Assume participants can cope without support




Research focusing on mental health and wellbeing is common in psychology but carries heightened ethical responsibility, particularly in student research contexts. While such topics are not prohibited, Research Ethics Committees closely scrutinise how constructs are defined, measured, and communicated to participants. Students must be especially careful to distinguish between research-oriented measurement and any form of clinical assessment or diagnosis.
Undergraduate and postgraduate taught students are not qualified clinicians, and therefore must not design studies that imply diagnosis, screening, or evaluation of mental disorders. Even widely used instruments (e.g., depression, anxiety, stress scales) must be framed explicitly as self-report research measures assessing experiences or traits, not as tools for identifying clinical conditions.
Mental health research also increases the likelihood of participant distress. As such, ethics applications must demonstrate clear risk mitigation strategies, including advance warnings, the right to skip questions, withdrawal without penalty, and robust debriefing procedures. Appropriate support signposting (e.g., NHS, GP, university wellbeing services, crisis lines) must be included and tailored to the nature of the topic.
Students should also consider the cumulative burden of questions, especially when combining multiple mental health measures or sensitive topics. RECs may reject studies that appear overly intrusive, excessive, or poorly justified relative to the research question.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Use non-diagnostic, research-appropriate self-report measures
✅ Clearly state that measures are not providing clinical assessment or diagnosis
✅ Provide clear content warnings and the option to skip questions
✅ Include tailored support and wellbeing signposting in debrief materials
✅ Justify the number and type of mental health measures used
❌ Attempt to diagnose, screen, or label participants
❌ Present scores as indicators of mental disorder or clinical risk
❌ Use mental health measures without a clear theoretical rationale
❌ Omit support information when researching distress-related topics

When designed carefully, mental health and wellbeing research can be ethically sound and scientifically valuable. However, students must demonstrate to the REC that participant welfare, scope of competence, and proportionality of risk have been prioritised throughout the study design.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Use non-diagnostic, research-appropriate measures
✅ Provide support signposting
❌ Attempt to diagnose or label participants
❌ Use measures implying clinical evaluation




Research involving children and young people under the age of 18 is subject to significantly heightened ethical, legal, and safeguarding requirements. Such participants are legally classified as a vulnerable population, meaning that Research Ethics Committees apply a much higher threshold when evaluating risk, consent, feasibility, and institutional responsibility.
For undergraduate psychology students, primary data collection with under-18s is generally not permitted within standard dissertation timelines. This is due to multiple practical and ethical constraints, including the requirement for enhanced safeguarding procedures, parental or guardian consent, school or institutional gatekeeper approval, and, in many cases, a Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check. Collectively, these processes typically exceed the duration of an academic year and cannot be guaranteed within undergraduate project timeframes.
Educational settings (e.g., schools, colleges, youth services) also impose their own ethics review processes and calendars, which operate independently of university RECs. Even where a research idea is ethically sound in principle, delays or refusals at the institutional level may render the project unviable.
Students who are strongly interested in educational or developmental psychology must therefore treat under-18 research as a long-term academic goal, more appropriate for postgraduate or doctoral study. Any such interest must be communicated to academic staff at least one year in advance, and only in collaboration with a member of the Psychology Department who has existing expertise, contacts, and safeguarding clearance in educational research.
Crucially, all students proposing research that might involve under-18s must prepare a fully independent backup project using adult participants. This backup must be capable of standing alone as the primary dissertation project in the event that ethics approval, school access, or DBS clearance is not obtained.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Inform academic staff at least one year in advance of any intention to work with under-18s
✅ Expect under-18 research to be more appropriate for postgraduate-level study
✅ Prepare a complete adult-participant backup project from the outset
✅ Consider alternative approaches (e.g., adult educators, trainee teachers, parents, or retrospective self-report designs)
❌ Attempt to recruit children or young people without full REC, parental, and institutional approval
❌ Assume DBS checks and school permissions can be completed within one academic year
❌ Design a dissertation that depends solely on under-18 access

Researchers must recognise participants as autonomous agents with the right to make informed, voluntary decisions about participation.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Provide clear, accessible information and consent procedures
✅ Respect participant autonomy and withdrawal rights
❌ Coerce or mislead participants
❌ Deny or obscure withdrawal options




Research must be methodologically sound, theoretically justified, and conducted with honesty and transparency.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Use validated, appropriate methods
✅ Justify all methodological choices
❌ Conduct research without planning or justification
❌ Fabricate or misrepresent data or methods




Researchers must consider broader social, institutional, and cultural consequences of their work, including cultural sensitivity, inclusivity, and environmental/institutional risks.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Protect vulnerable groups and consider societal impacts
✅ Address potential misuses of findings
✅ Ensure cultural and demographic considerations are justified
✅ Mitigate environmental or institutional risks
❌ Conduct research likely to harm or stigmatise participants
❌ Ignore wider implications of findings




All research involves some level of risk. Ethical research requires these risks to be proportionate, justified, and actively mitigated.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Assess and mitigate risks
✅ Provide debriefing and support mechanisms
❌ Expose participants to unnecessary harm
❌ Assume participants can manage distress without support

Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Anonymise or pseudonymise participant data
✅ Explain limits of confidentiality in consent forms
❌ Share identifiable data without explicit consent
❌ Store sensitive data on personal devices without institutional approval




Researchers must maintain professional boundaries and minimise power imbalances.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Maintain professional relationships and boundaries
✅ Avoid implicit pressure due to authority or institutional roles
❌ Exploit relationships or position of power
❌ Coerce participation through hierarchical pressure

Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Collect only necessary demographic information
✅ Provide references for why each demographic variable is needed
❌ Collect all demographics without justification
❌ Include sensitive demographics without rationale




Use of incentives must not coerce participation. Participants can withdraw without losing rewards.
Do / Do Not Guidance:

✅ Explain incentives and withdrawal rights
✅ Ensure rewards are proportionate and ethical
❌ Use incentives to pressure participation
❌ Link participation to rewards in a way that creates undue influence

Research involving sensitive topics requires careful ethical justification, proportionate risk management, and clear evidence that the research question cannot be addressed using less intrusive means. Sensitive topics may include, but are not limited to: trauma, abuse, violence, self-harm, suicide, substance use, discrimination, illegal behaviour, bereavement, sexual behaviour, or highly personal life experiences.
Research Ethics Committees assess sensitive-topic proposals with particular attention to participant vulnerability, likelihood of distress, and researcher preparedness. Students must demonstrate that they have anticipated potential emotional, psychological, or social risks and have put in place appropriate safeguards. This includes recognising that participants may have lived experience related to the topic, even if the study does not explicitly recruit clinical or vulnerable populations.
Ethical viability depends not only on what is being studied, but how it is studied. Question wording, task framing, sequencing of measures, and the context in which participation occurs all influence participant wellbeing. Studies that are overly intrusive, poorly justified, or disproportionate to the level of academic training are likely to be rejected or require substantial revision.
Students are expected to work closely with their supervisor when proposing sensitive topics and to engage in early ethical reflection rather than treating ethics as an administrative step. In many cases, Research Ethics Committees will expect explicit justification for why a sensitive topic is necessary, how harm will be minimised, and how participants will be supported both during and after participation.

✅ Provide a clear theoretical and empirical justification for studying the sensitive topic
✅ Demonstrate proportionality between research aims and participant burden
✅ Include content warnings and remind participants of their right to skip questions
✅ Implement robust debriefing and signposting procedures
✅ Consult supervisors early and revise designs where risk is disproportionate
❌ Include sensitive questions without strong justification
❌ Use graphic, explicit, or unnecessarily detailed materials
❌ Assume participants will not experience distress
❌ Proceed without clear plans for managing adverse reactions

Students must show the REC that participant welfare, feasibility, and institutional responsibility have been prioritised at every stage of the research process.

❌ Assume participants can cope without support




Research focusing on mental health and wellbeing is common in psychology but carries heightened ethical responsibility, particularly in student research contexts. While such topics are not prohibited, Research Ethics Committees closely scrutinise how constructs are defined, measured, and communicated to participants. Students must be especially careful to distinguish between research-oriented measurement and any form of clinical assessment or diagnosis.
Undergraduate and postgraduate taught students are not qualified clinicians, and therefore must not design studies that imply diagnosis, screening, or evaluation of mental disorders. Appropriate support signposting (e.g., NHS, GP, university wellbeing services, crisis lines) must be included and tailored to the nature of the topic.
Students should also consider the cumulative burden of questions, especially when combining multiple mental health measures or sensitive topics. RECs may reject studies that appear overly intrusive, excessive, or poorly justified relative to the research question.

✅ Use non-diagnostic, research-appropriate self-report measures
✅ Clearly state that measures are not providing clinical assessment or diagnosis
✅ Provide clear content warnings and the option to skip questions
✅ Include tailored support and wellbeing signposting in debrief materials
✅ Justify the number and type of mental health measures used
❌ Attempt to diagnose, screen, or label participants
❌ Present scores as indicators of mental disorder or clinical risk
❌ Use mental health measures without a clear theoretical rationale
❌ Omit support information when researching distress-related topics

✅ Use non-diagnostic, research-appropriate measures
✅ Provide support signposting
❌ Attempt to diagnose or label participants
❌ Use measures implying clinical evaluation

title: Experimental Repository
text:
Psychologists regularly use experiments to collect data about peoples cognitions, personality, perceptions, or behaviour (amongst other things).
However, there are a number of solutions available for conducting data collection with behavioural tasks, such as the Stroop task, Go/No-Go task, or N-back task. At Wrexham University, we predominantly use 2 solutions; Psychopy and Gorilla.
Each has different strengths and weaknesses, so you should consider which system is best for your research. The video below provides a brief introduction to Gorilla.sc and PsychoPy. We have also listed various experimental tasks.

title: Resources
text:
The Psychology Department is committed to supporting open science, transparent research practices, and the use of professional software in both teaching and independent projects. Below is a selection of recommended resources that are freely available to students and staff. We describe as well how we as the psychology technicians use these tools down below to help our students.




Questionnaire Page
Experimental Page






Quarto A publishing system for creating reproducible documents, dashboards, and interactive reports. Useful for writing, data analysis, and creating professional portfolios. We use this to output a plethora of content for students.
Open Reproducibility Resources
A growing repository and set of tools that ensure transparency in research, demonstrations and teaching materials. Primarily on Gorilla.sc Open Materials.






Python A versatile language for data analysis, statistics, machine learning, and experiment design. Widely supported across psychology and cognitive science research.
R A powerful statistical environment for quantitative analysis, data visualization, and reproducible research.
Julia A high-performance programming language particularly suited for numerical computing, data analysis, and modelling. Widely used in research requiring speed and scalability, and increasingly adopted in psychology and cognitive science applications.






Open Broadcaster Software A free and open source software for video recording and live streaming.
DaVinci Resolve A professional-grade video editing suite with a free version. Suitable for creating teaching material, experiment stimuli, or presentation content.
Audacity An open-source audio editing tool, useful for preparing stimuli and cleaning recordings.
GIMP / Inkscape Free alternatives to Photoshop and Illustrator, excellent for creating figures, posters, and experimental graphics.





Our Psychology Technicians use advanced virtual reality tools to help students design, build, and test experiments:

Unity Experimental Framework – A flexible platform for creating interactive VR experiments and simulations.
Unity & Unity Hub – Centralized management for Unity projects, versions, and collaboration.
Unreal Engine – High-fidelity engine for immersive VR environments and realistic experimental scenarios.
Blender – 3D modelling and animation software to design custom stimuli and experimental assets.






GitHub / GitLab Collaborative platforms for version control and code sharing. Essential for research teams practicing open science.


For further support, guidance, or training recommendations, please contact:

title: About the Psychology Technicians
text:
The Psychology Technicians at Wrexham University provide essential technical support, training, and expertise to staff and students in the Psychology Department.
We ensure that teaching, research, and student projects are supported with the right tools, equipment, and guidance.



We support the Psychology Department in three key areas:

Teaching Support
We prepare, maintain, and run equipment for practical classes, workshops, and open days.
From laboratory demonstrations to experimental psychology tasks, we ensure everything runs smoothly.
Research Support
We help staff and students set up studies, collect data, and manage specialist equipment.
Our expertise covers Biopac, Tobii Eye Tracking, CANTAB, and software such as PsychoPy, R, and Gorilla.
Student Projects
Undergraduate and postgraduate students rely on our guidance for dissertations, independent projects, and experiments.
We provide training, troubleshooting, and technical advice to make sure students can carry out their work confidently.




We’re always happy to support colleagues across the department and to collaborate on interdisciplinary projects. For undergraduate students, we strongly encourage you to discuss your third-year project ideas with us as early as possible. Many projects require careful planning, and we can often design experiments tailored to your specific needs. This may involve building bespoke solutions from scratch or identifying and adapting reliable “off-the-shelf” tools. Early conversations ensure we have the time to create a setup that works effectively and supports your research aims.

title: Equipment and Facilities
text:
The Psychology Department at Wrexham University has a wide range of specialist equipment to support teaching, research, and student projects. Our technicians provide training, setup, and ongoing support to ensure equipment is used safely and effectively.




Tobii Pro Spark Eye Trackers
Portable, user-friendly devices for high-quality eye-tracking research. Suitable for projects in attention, cognition, and visual behaviour.
Biopac Systems
A comprehensive suite for recording physiological signals such as EDA (electrodermal activity), ECG (electrocardiogram), EMG (electromyogram), and respiration. Ideal for psychophysiology and health psychology studies.
BioRadio
Wireless physiological data acquisition system, particularly useful for mobility studies and projects requiring real-time bio-signal monitoring.
CANTAB (Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery)
A widely used computerized system for assessing cognitive functions such as memory, attention, and executive function.
Virtual Reality Equipment
VR headsets and software support for immerse experimental paradigms using the Unity Experimental Framework. Useful in applied psychology, perception studies, and innovative research designs.
High-Quality Audio-Visual Recording
Digital cameras, microphones, and editing tools for experimental recording, behavioural coding, and presentation material.





The Psychology technicians are trained in the latest, simulation training

VR/AR/XR Implementations Designing and delivering immersive experiences using Virtual, Augmented, and Extended Reality to simulate real-world environments for teaching, training, and research purposes.
Immersive Simulation & Scenario-Based Learning Developing tailored scenarios and role-play environments that allow students to experience, practice, and reflect on psychological concepts and professional skills in safe, controlled conditions.
Immersive Studio Toolkit Applying advanced studio tools and platforms to create high-quality, interactive content that integrates seamlessly into teaching and experimental setups.
Interactive Wearables & Portable Technology Utilizing wearable devices (such as biometric sensors, VR headsets, and mobile-based platforms) to gather real-time physiological and behavioral data, supporting innovative psychological research.
3D Scanning, Photogrammetry & Digital Twins Capturing physical environments and objects to build digital replicas, enabling highly accurate reconstructions for analysis, training, or experimental immersion.
Motion Capture for Immersive Performance & Interaction Implementing motion capture systems to study movement, behavior, and interaction in both research and applied contexts, bringing realism and precision into immersive simulations. —





Equipment can only be booked in advance via the Psychology Technicians with prior approval from your supervisor.

Training is provided where specialist knowledge is required (e.g., ECG, EDA, Eye Tracking).

Students are encouraged to discuss project needs early so we can plan suitable training and ensure availability of equipment.

title: Psychometric Scales Repository
text:
Psychologists regularly use psychometric scales to collect data about peoples attitudes, personality, perceptions, or behaviour (amongst other things).
The questionnaires, scales, and inventories listed below are a great place to get started on looking for a suitable measure for your research. Although, there are many measures that are listed below. You may find a more suitable measure by conducting a Library Search, using Google Scholar, or by other means. If you come across something interesting that you think we should look at, please let us know!



We do not have copyright authority over some measures and cannot grant permission for use.
We recommend students from Wrexham University to use the “Free for use” scales. If you require a particular scale, then please contact the author(s) of the questionnaire for use permissions. However, please consult your supervisor before proceeding.
The scales are provided solely as a courtesy to help Dissertation students develop their experiments efficiently, to get their projects underway, and provide module leaders resources for their teaching modules. Not all scales are provided and will only be available when Wrexham students, researchers and module leaders provide the appropriate evidence of licensing or permission.
Please note that the scales may contain errors. Therefore, if you identify any inaccuracies, please kindly contact us at psychology.technician@wrexham.ac.uk so we can rectify any of the scales. While every effort has been made to ensure accuracy, these materials are prepared by humans and should be carefully checked before use in any research or teaching capacity.
Additionally, it is the responsibility of each researcher to ensure the information they use from this repository is accurate and complies with copyright law. Some scales will also dictate that you cannot modify or adapt the contents of the scale, so if you should use a scale from this repository it should follow the appropriate copyright licensing from the original publishers. For more information about copyright and how it applies to research materials, please see the UK Government’s guidance on copyright: https://www.gov.uk/copyright.
Please note: Due to the volume of requests, emails requesting permission for use will not receive a reply. We are also unable to provide author contact information.
If you have further questions, you can contact: psychology.technician@wrexham.ac.uk
